div.head: To his good Friend Master Robert Norton, on his Practise of Artillery.
div.l: I Told you Friend, before your Booke I'de write,
But not Idolatrize with Poetick spright,
Doing our loues much wrong, in little right.
The Times necessity, and each Studious minde
Will make it prayse it selfe, which you shall finde
By'ts oft impression, th'Art being here refinde.
Yet (iustly I confesse) I haue been showne
Bookes that sell well, yet not for what's their owne,
But for Commendators before them knowne.
And this integrity Commands me say,
That to the Trueth thou shewst the rightest way,
For Young Artists, and here the Old may stay.
For here th'are satissied with small dispence
Of Purse, or Braines, of Skill the quintessence,
Drawne from the Antick Artists excellence.
I know rich Iewells may themselues commend,
Which be such Bookes (that for the publique end)
With Iudgement written are, So thine good Friend.
